awd_titl_txt: PIRE: High Temperature Ceramic Fibers: Polymer-Based Manufacturing, Nanostructure, and Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
Gurpreet Singh (Kansas State University), Himanshu Jain (Lehigh University), Peter Kroll (University of Texas at Arlington), Alexandra Navrotsky (University of California - Davis), Rishi Raj (University of Colorado Boulder)

The single crystal superalloy blade for gas turbines may have been the most significant development in energy and transportation sectors in the last century. It empowered our military prowess, and enabled civilian aircraft to fly half way around the world. Further advancement in the operating temperature of gas turbines made with metallic materials, however, is limited by their melting points. So the next phase must be based upon high-temperature ceramics. These high-tech materials for gas turbine engines are composites of ceramic fibers infiltrated with a ceramic matrix, both made of non-oxide ceramics such as silicon carbide. The fibers, which are the foundation of this ceramic matrix composite (CMC) technology, are generally derived through thermal decomposition of organosilicon polymers. The CMCs hold the promise of quantum leaps in the operating temperature of gas turbines, which may increase engine thrust by 25% while decreasing fuel consumption by 10% just within the next few years. Unfortunately, the United States is far behind Japan and Europe that lead the science and technology of processing and innovation in non-oxide fiber fabrication. To make the US competitive this PIRE program will expand research in the basic science and technology and train professionals with expertise in fiber processing and properties. The program will leverage the relationships that researchers in the US have established with their counterparts overseas. Specifically, the US PIRE team members will bring expertise in structure and thermo-chemo-mechanical property characterization of polymer-derived ceramics (PDC), whereas international partners will offer expertise in pre-ceramic polymers and non-oxide ceramic fibers. Together they will train the next generation of students in this crucial area of materials science and engineering. Seven to ten doctoral and twenty undergraduate research scholars from the US will receive training on ceramic fiber research via dual degree programs and exchange visits to PIRE member institutions in Japan and Europe (UK, France, Germany, Italy). The community built under this program will include young researchers comprising of at least 50% female, underrepresented and first-generation-to-attend-college students. They will serve as the backbone for continued innovation and scientific research on ceramic fibers far into the future. The research team foresees that the fiber program will evolve into a full-fledged CMC program, where the matrix and the fibers are manufactured from polymers in the United States, within a decade.

The research component of this PIRE project will focus on developing the next generation multi-component PDC fibers of carefully selected compositions within the Si/C/N/O systems through systematic understanding of structure-property-processing correlations, leading to superior properties. Key aspects of the project are: (a) design of new pre-ceramic polymers suitable for drawing fibers, (b) thermolysis of pre-ceramic polymers to obtain multi-component ceramic fibers with desired morphology, chemical stability and microstructure, (c) measurements of creep and thermochemical properties, and (d) modeling of the oxidation behavior of ceramic fibers. Ab-initio calculations will be performed to correlate experimental measurements, such as from high temperature calorimetry, to the nanostructure of ceramic fibers. Further, economic evaluation and the impact of PDC fiber manufacture on resources will be assessed to determine the implications and viability of new, science-based technologies at the earliest stages. Successful completion of the project will thus lead to: (i) the creation of new US-based CMC science and technology, (ii) a cadre of undergraduate and graduate students who will implement this know-how in US academia, industry and national laboratories, and (iii) a vibrant international community that through its diversity will greatly accelerate progress in this critical field.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual contributions:

The US-Europe/Asia research and education partnership, facilitated by the NSF PIRE Program, actively promoted collaborative efforts in developing improved understanding related to the synthesis and use of preceramic polymers in the fabrication of polymer-derived ceramic materials (PDCs). Our team recognized the immense value of effectively combining research expertise and infrastructure across the universities in the US and Europe. Specifically, the team investigated different aspects related to PDCs--precursor and fiber processing, their use in ceramic matrix composites and establishing structure/property/processing relationships by use of cross-correlations techniques such as the high temperature calorimetry, near ambient pressure or NAP X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and nuclear magnetic resonance. Atomistic simulations were conducted to understand experimental observations. Significant breakthroughs were achieved in understanding the structure and properties of multicomponent amorphous PDCs such as SiO(X)CN (where X is a dopant atom) that can be produced inexpensively compared to traditional silicon carbide.

Working collaboratively, we investigated the thermodynamic stability of the SiaOb(M)cCd PDCs derived from polymeric precursors incorporating metal fillers (M): Ta, Nb, and Hf. Enthalpies of formation relative to crystalline components were obtained from thermodynamic measurements by high temperature oxide melt solution calorimetry. The results indicate strong thermodynamic drive for carbothermal reduction of metal oxide domains. Ta metal fillers stabilize the formation of SiO3C bonds. Ultimately, the choice of metal filler influences composition, structural evolution, and thermodynamic stability of PDCs. 

Atomistic simulations were employed to model Si-C-O-H structures and investigate the mechanical properties of SiCO materials. The impact of composition, density, carbon content, and carbon morphology were explored individually to disentangle mutual dependencies that were otherwise difficult to separate in experimental studies. The outcomes reveal the strong impact of the morphology of the free carbon phase on the mechanical properties of SiCO ceramic and highlight that tubular segregations of free carbon enhance the moduli of the material. Additionally, we developed new interaction potentials to simulate reactions at high temperatures.

The team developed environmentally friendly processing methods for PDCs fibers--composite materials prepared from amorphous SiOC PDCs are not only capable of sustaining higher temperatures but also manufactured with comparatively lower energy input costs. For example, preceramic polymers were developed or modified to produce PDC fiber mats by a one-step spinning process in air with ceramization occurring at 800 °C. In addition, procedures were developed for the preparation of composite PDC fibers from nanoscale filler reinforcements consisting of 2-D nanosheets for emerging functional and electrochemical applications. Bespoke test jigs were designed for assessing mechanical properties of extremely thin (one tenth to hundredth of mm) non-woven fiber mats of PDC fibers. In addition, a new deep-learning tool has been developed and validated that allows automated identification of different phases and damage in X-ray CT images of ceramic composites formed from polymer-derived fibers and polymer-derived matrices. This method involves analysis of very large data sets, which cannot be done manually. 

Thus far, the project has led to 40 journal articles, 3 issued patents and over 125 conference presentations. 

Broader Impacts or Societal Contributions: 

Overall, this project produced several impactful outcomes--the international collaborations resulting from this effort have led to a holistic understanding of the interconnections among structure, bonding, and thermodynamic stability of PDCs and similar carbon-containing hybrid materials. Such understanding is useful in building a framework for the predictive design and synthesis of PDCs with high thermodynamic stability and desired functionality, which are important for the research communities, including in the field of chemical engineering, material science, and solid-state chemistry.

The project recruited and trained 35 undergraduate student researchers, more than two-thirds of those being female students. All UG researchers participated in summer international research collaborations and cultural experiences in Europe. Nine UG students (6 female, 3 male) continue to pursue PhD degrees. Hitherto, the project supported and produced 6 MS theses and 11 PhD dissertations. Seven annual international summer PIRE PDC workshops were organized to disseminate the findings of the project, and promote networking among member universities, and collaboration with industry and Air Force Research Lab.  Participation in weeklong annual workshop enabled a cohort of US students to engage with the industry professionals and learn about various technological processes related to use of PDCs in the aerospace and defense. They received valuable firsthand knowledge of the bottlenecks related to translation of discoveries made in a university lab to economical production at large scale. Thus, they gained a perspective of real applications in industry, which is often remiss in traditional graduate training programs. The project has led to establishment of a lasting co-operative network among the US, European (10 universities from 4 countries) and Asian universities, as well the US academia (6 universities), industry, and national labs with interests in PDCs. These collaborations will not only continue to produce well-trained university educated professionals for industry but also enable groundbreaking discoveries beyond the PIRE project. 

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: Gurpreet Singh
